data.title: Delek US raises enterprise optimization plan target to $200M annual run rate as company accelerates economic separation with DKL
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Delek US Holdings, Inc. (DK) Q4 2025

Management View

  • Avigal Soreq, President and CEO, highlighted 2025 as a transformational year, stating that "we have made progress on all fronts, including improving the free cash flow profile of the company and increasing the economic separation between DK and DKL." Soreq announced that Delek reported an adjusted EPS of $0.44 and adjusted EBITDA of approximately $226 million for Q4 2025, excluding SRE, and raised the enterprise optimization plan (EOP) target to at least $200 million on an annual run rate basis.
  • Soreq detailed that DKL achieved a record year with approximately $536 million in adjusted EBITDA and set 2026 EBITDA guidance for DKL at $520 million to $560 million. He emphasized DKL’s progress in sour gas solutions and third-party EBITDA expected to exceed 80% in 2026. "Achieving this level of economic separation has been cornerstone of our sum-of-the-parts strategy," Soreq said.
  • Soreq reported a successful turnaround at Big Spring refinery, stating, "The focus of this turnaround is to further enhance reliability and operational flexibility, positioning the refinery for improved cost structure and margin capture." He also noted the EOP's growing impact, estimating a $50 million contribution to Q4 2025 P&L and increasing the annual EOP improvement expectation to at least $200 million.
  • Soreq described the monetization of 2023 and 2024 RINs, rapid use of proceeds to reduce the inventory intermediation agreement, and projected a $40 million annual improvement in free cash flow from this restructuring. He reaffirmed a commitment to shareholder returns, referencing $15 million in dividends and $20 million in share buybacks during the quarter.
  • Mark Hobbs, Executive VP & CFO, stated, "For the fourth quarter, Delek had net income of $78 million or $1.26 per share. Adjusted net income was $143 million or $2.31 per share, and adjusted EBITDA was approximately $375 million."
  • Hobbs highlighted that logistics delivered approximately $142 million in adjusted EBITDA and that cash flow from operations, adjusted for working capital and SREs, was $119 million, an improvement of $211 million from the prior year.

Outlook

  • Soreq communicated that EOP-related cash flow improvement expectations have been raised to at least $200 million annually. DKL's 2026 EBITDA guidance was announced in the range of $520 million to $560 million. Soreq also noted, "we expect DKL third-party EBITDA to exceed 80%."
  • Hobbs provided Q1 2026 throughput guidance: Tyler at 70,000–74,000 barrels per day, El Dorado at 66,000–71,000 barrels per day, Big Spring at 22,000–28,000 barrels per day due to the planned turnaround, and Krotz Springs at 82,000–86,000 barrels per day. System throughput target is 240,000–259,000 barrels per day.
  • Operating expense for Q1 2026 is expected to be $210 million to $220 million, G&A at $47 million to $52 million, D&A between $100 million and $110 million, and net interest expense between $75 million and $85 million.

Financial Results

  • Delek reported adjusted net income of $143 million or $2.31 per share and adjusted EBITDA of approximately $375 million for Q4 2025. Excluding SREs, adjusted EBITDA and adjusted EPS were $226 million and $0.44 per share, respectively.
  • The refining segment's adjusted EBITDA declined by $91 million from the previous quarter, driven primarily by seasonality. Supply and marketing contributed $23 million to Q4, with $35 million from wholesale marketing. Asphalt posted a loss of $4.2 million. Logistics delivered $142 million in adjusted EBITDA for the quarter.
  • Cash flow provided by operations was $503 million, including a $26 million net inflow from changes in working capital. Financing activities included $380 million in paydown of the inventory intermediation agreement, $20 million in share repurchases, $15 million in dividends, and $22 million in DKL distribution payments.

Q&A

  • Douglas George Blyth Leggate, Wolfe Research: Asked about cash inflow and recognition for SREs already awarded, and risks for '25 through '28 RINs. Soreq responded that SRE is "a huge, huge topic" impacting many refineries and remains critical. Hobbs added that $360 million was monetized from prior year SREs, used to pay down $380 million under the IIA, reducing annual interest expense by at least $40 million. Bhardwaj noted additional monetization is expected in the first half of 2026.
  • Paul Cheng, Scotiabank: Inquired about DKL consolidation timeline and Big Spring refinery turnaround initiatives. Soreq stated the goal is full value reflection in share and unit price, noted reduction in DK's DKL ownership to around 60%, and described multiple strategic options. On Big Spring, Soreq emphasized a focus on reliability, crude slate optimization, and product mix; no major new capital projects are included in the current turnaround.
  • Alexa Petrick, Goldman Sachs: Asked about drivers of raised cash flow guidance and capital allocation priorities. Soreq described EOP as a "lifestyle" across the company and stated, "we are not stopping here" regarding future EOP improvements. On capital allocation, Soreq reiterated a disciplined approach, maintaining dividends, balancing buybacks and the balance sheet.
  • Jason Gabelman, TD Cowen: Queried supply and marketing line volatility and DKL transaction details. Soreq and Bhardwaj explained seasonal and structural drivers, with some volatility expected but core business improvements ongoing. Wright noted recent DKL transactions further economic separation, but EBITDA impact is not material.
  • Ryan Todd, Piper Sandler: Asked about sustainability of margin capture. Soreq identified safe operations, strong commercial activity, and EOP as key, with post-turnaround improvements at Tyler and KSR. Bhardwaj added EOP-driven product and yield enhancements.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts focused on structural cash flow improvements, SRE recognition, and capital allocation, probing for sustainability and upside. The tone was generally positive, with some pressing for clarity on one-time versus repeatable gains and strategic separation.
  • Management maintained a confident and upbeat tone in prepared remarks, using phrases such as "very excited" and "proud of the progress," but became more detailed and occasionally defensive in response to probing on SREs and cash flow sustainability. Soreq described EOP as "a lifestyle" and Hobbs highlighted the magnitude of recent cash flow improvements.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management's tone remained confident, with increased emphasis on operational culture and strategic execution. Analysts continued to probe for clarity on repeatable performance, with a slightly more granular focus on segment-specific drivers and separation plans.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • EOP target increased from at least $180 million in Q3 to at least $200 million in Q4, reflecting ongoing internal improvements.
  • DKL full-year EBITDA guidance rose from $500–$520 million in Q3 to $520–$560 million for 2026 in Q4, underlining expectations for continued logistics growth.
  • Throughput guidance for Q1 2026 was provided in more detail due to the planned Big Spring turnaround, while the previous quarter highlighted seasonal trends.
  • Management’s confidence in monetizing SRE-related RINs accelerated, with faster-than-expected cash realization in Q4 compared to the projected 6-9 months in Q3.
  • Analysts maintained focus on SRE sustainability, segment cash flow drivers, and capital allocation, with increased attention to economic separation initiatives in the current quarter.

Risks and Concerns

  • Soreq acknowledged ongoing efforts to secure full value for 2019–2022 RINs, referencing "invalid relief" and the uncertain outcome of pending SRE petitions.
  • Management recognized seasonality as a primary driver of refining segment EBITDA decline and noted expected volatility in supply and marketing contributions.
  • Legislative and regulatory risks regarding SREs were discussed, with management expressing belief in continued policy support but acknowledging that EPA decisions are outside company control.
  • Potential volatility in third-party EBITDA at DKL and market-driven factors, such as pipeline developments, were cited as areas to monitor.

Final Takeaway

Management emphasized that 2025 represented a pivotal year for Delek, marked by record DKL performance, accelerated monetization of SRE-related RINs, and a further increase in enterprise optimization plan targets. The company highlighted ongoing operational improvements, disciplined capital allocation, and the strategic advancement of DK and DKL economic separation as key contributors to future value creation. Management’s focus remains on driving sustainable free cash flow, maintaining a strong balance sheet, and executing on growth and efficiency initiatives into 2026.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Life beyond beer: Anheuser-Busch adds BeatBox to its portfolio, hits 5-year share price high
data.description:
Anheuser-Busch InBev (BUD) officially welcomed BeatBox to its fast-growing Beyond Beer Portfolio. 

The beer giant announced late last year that it acquired an 85% stake in BeatBox for a purchase price of up to approximately $490M  with a path to 100% ownership after five years based on a predetermined pricing formula. Notably, BeatBox was the number five fastest-growing brand by dollar sales in the U.S. hard beverage industry.

BeatBox originated in Austin, Texas, and gained popularity after its founders' appearance on Shark Tank in 2014. The ready-to-drink cocktail brand is now known for its lively "party-in-a-box" approach, offering bold, fruit-forward flavors like Party Punch, Blue Razzberry, and Peach Punch, as well as Hard Tea and Lemonade options. The beverages are primarily wine-based but also come in malt-based variants, with alcohol by volume levels typically at 11.1% or 8.0%. BeatBox's drinks are vegan, use certified food colorings, and are designed to be smooth and non-carbonated.

Anheuser-Busch InBev (BUD) said the deal adds a world-class brand to its fast-growing Beyond Beer portfolio, which already includes Cutwater Spirits, NÜTRL Vodka Seltzer, and Phorm Energy. 

Shares of Anheuser-Busch InBev (BUD) are up more than 26% on a year-to-date basis and printed a new five-year high earlier on Friday.

data.title: TTEC outlines 7.6% adjusted EBITDA growth target for 2026 as AI adoption approaches 100%
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: TTEC Holdings, Inc. (TTEC) Q4 2025

Management View

  • Kenneth Tuchman, Founder, Chairman & CEO, stated that "2025 was a pivotal year for TTEC, one in which we met our financial commitments, improved our balance sheet and fortified our position as the leader in AI-enabled CX." He highlighted full-year revenue of $2.136 billion, exceeding the high end of guidance, with adjusted EBITDA of $214 million and cash flow generation of $83 million, which allowed for a $70 million reduction in credit facility borrowings.
  • Tuchman emphasized "onetime goodwill noncash impairment on a portion of our TTEC Digital segment in the fourth quarter" due to a decline in market capitalization. He stressed this was a noncash expense with "no impact on our broader ability to execute our strategy or the value of our CX technology solutions."
  • New business launches in both Engage and Digital segments increased year-over-year, and the company attracted numerous new clients with its "AI forward and vertical solutions approach." Tuchman announced key leadership appointments: Alfredo Rizzo as Chief Technology Officer and Ramki Desiraju as Chief Operating Officer at TTEC Digital, expected to accelerate the strategic road map.
  • Tuchman explained ongoing investments in AI-enabled solutions and projected "near 100% AI adoption with our current clients by the end of this year."
  • Kenneth Wagers, Chief Financial Officer, reported, "On a consolidated basis for fourth quarter 2025 compared to the prior year period, revenue was $570 million, a slight increase over the prior year period of $567 million. Adjusted EBITDA was $62 million or 10.9% of revenue compared to $51 million or 9%. Operating income was $48 million or 8.4% of revenue compared to $35 million or 6.2%, and earnings per share was $0.47 compared to $0.19."

Outlook

  • Wagers provided 2026 guidance, stating "GAAP revenue of $2.03 billion, a decrease over the prior year of 5%, adjusted EBITDA of $230 million, an increase of 7.6% over the prior year and 11.3% of revenue compared to 10% in the prior year. Non-GAAP operating income of $169 million, an increase of 9% over the prior year and 8.3% of revenue compared to 7.3% in the prior year. Non-GAAP earnings per share of $1.19, an increase of 9% over the prior year."
  • The company expects "a decline in revenue of approximately 4%" in the Engage segment and an "8.4%" revenue decline in Digital, primarily due to product resale contraction, but with continued profitability and margin improvement.
  • Management expects "the phasing of our profitability to be more weighted in the second half of 2026 with approximately 52% of our revenue coming in the second half of the year."

Financial Results

  • Consolidated full-year 2025 results included revenue of $2.14 billion and adjusted EBITDA of $214 million. Operating income reached $155 million, with earnings per share at $1.10.
  • Engage segment fourth quarter revenue was $444 million, with operating income at $36 million. Full-year Engage revenue was $1.67 billion, with operating income at $101 million.
  • Digital segment fourth quarter revenue reached $125 million, with operating income of $12 million. Full-year Digital revenue was $469 million, with operating income at $54 million.
  • The company recorded a $193 million noncash impairment charge in the Digital segment and an additional $12 million noncash tax charge, bringing the total to $205 million.
  • Free cash flow for 2025 was $83 million, capital expenditures were $38 million, and net debt at year end was $825 million.

Q&A

  • George Sutton, Craig-Hallum, asked about near 100% AI adoption and ongoing work with customers. Tuchman responded that the focus is on enabling clients with AI across all operational functions, targeting "100% by year-end, which means that at minimum, our clients are taking advantage of all of the internal tools that we utilize."
  • Margaret Nolan, William Blair, asked about revenue mix shift between project-based and recurring revenue. Tuchman explained the digital business aims for "on average a 50% recurring revenue, and we're currently achieving that, maybe even a bit more."
  • Yu Lee, Guggenheim Securities, questioned the offshore mix shift and its impact on onshore revenue. Tuchman clarified, "the majority of the revenue that we have onshore, legally, we don't have the ability or the client doesn't have the ability to move offshore under the current regulations."
  • Lee also asked about clients pushing for AI efficiency savings. Tuchman replied, "that's actually not even -- that's not -- that's -- so far, we're not actually encountering that."
  • Vincent Colicchio, Barrington Research, asked about benefiting from consolidation. Tuchman responded, "we think that's going to, over time, accelerate as clients realize that the concept of having 10 vendors makes very little sense."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts’ tone was inquisitive with a focus on AI adoption, revenue mix, and operational shifts, expressing skepticism in areas such as offshore mix and revenue headwinds.
  • Management spoke with confidence during prepared remarks, especially on profitability and AI strategy, but responses during Q&A occasionally included clarifying language and lengthy explanations, such as "I'm sorry, I thought I answered that…" and "I know I sound like a broken record on this, but it's really important for people to understand this."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, analysts’ tone remained probing, while management’s confidence appeared more assertive, particularly regarding AI adoption and strategic direction.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance language shifted from maintaining to targeting improvement in adjusted EBITDA, margin, and operating income for 2026, while acknowledging revenue decline.
  • Strategic focus moved more distinctly toward AI-enabled solutions, offshore delivery, and high-margin engagements.
  • Analysts continued to press on the specifics of AI adoption, recurring revenue, and cost structure, but questions around the impact of AI on profitability and the practical pace of transformation were more pronounced.
  • Key metrics such as free cash flow and profitability improved compared to the prior quarter, while revenue guidance was repositioned to highlight margin over top-line growth.
  • Management’s tone became more forward-looking, articulating the path to near-total AI enablement and explicit margin expansion goals.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management cited a "decline in our market capitalization" and industry "AI overhang casting a shadow over valuations for CX, IT and SaaS-based business services companies."
  • A $205 million noncash impairment in the Digital segment was noted as a consequence of market shifts away from legacy recurring managed service offerings.
  • The company acknowledged near-term revenue headwinds due to "rationalization of certain clients and lines of businesses that are underperforming" and an "8.4%" Digital segment revenue decline driven by lower product resale.
  • Management is prioritizing profitability and margin over top-line growth, with continued deleveraging efforts and investments in high-value, complex client engagements.

Final Takeaway

TTEC’s management reported a year of financial commitments met and margin improvement, highlighted by a shift toward AI-enabled solutions and a focus on higher-value, complex client engagements. While 2026 revenue is expected to decline, the company targets adjusted EBITDA growth and margin expansion. Management emphasized that noncash impairment charges do not affect operational strategy, and reaffirmed the company’s focus on profitability, cash flow, and strategic transformation in response to evolving market dynamics and AI-driven opportunities.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Baron International Growth Fund adds and exits multiple positions in Q4
data.description:
• Baron International Growth Fund underperformed with a return of 2.96% in Q4 2025, as compared to the MSCI ACWI ex USA Index, which gained 5.05% for the same period.
  • During Q4 2025, the fund initiated new positions in Euronext N.V. (EUXTF), Brunello Cucinelli S.p.A. (BCUCF) and Mitsui Fudosan (MTSFY).
  • In Q4 2025, the fund exited Waga Energy SA, Godrej Consumer Products Limited, and DSM-Firmenich AG (KDSKF).
  • Source.

data.title: Eos Energy cut at Guggenheim on 'struggle' with financial forecasting, communication
data.description:
Eos Energy Enterprises (EOSE) -10.1% in Friday's trading, its second straight sharp decline that totals more than 40%, after reporting much lower than expected Q4 adjusted earnings and revenues while initiating below-consensus FY 2026 revenue guidance of $300M-$400M.

Guggenheim analyst Joseph Osha downgraded shares to Neutral from Buy, saying Eos Energy (EOSE) is making operational progress, but management is "not paying sufficient attention to financial forecasting and public targets," resulting in "disjointed and inconsistent financial information."

The problem for Eos Energy (EOSE) investors is "the company's continued inability to provide reasonable forecasts for its business," saying management was "confidently reiterating a higher number well into the quarter, when manufacturing operations would have already been experiencing problems," Osha wrote.

Weighing the stock's valuation, Osha said he still sees a "sufficient chance of success" to support an unchanged 28x multiple based on our much lower 2029 EBITDA estimate, still discounted back to the present at 8% per annum," which supports a Neutral rating.

data.title: TPG's exposure to failed UK-based MFS is about £44M - report
data.description:
TPG (TPG) joins the list of Wall Street lenders exposed to the failed UK mortgage finance firm, Market Financial Solutions, Bloomberg reported on Friday.

The global alternative asset management firm has £44M worth of exposure to MFS, a company spokesperson told the news outlet in an emailed statement.

The exposure is below 2% of MFS's loan exposures based on publicly reported figures, the spokesperson reportedly said.

The Fort Worth, Texas-based company is the latest name to be added to the list of Street lenders exposed to MFS insolvency.

data.title: Braemar Hotels outlines continued portfolio strength and strategic asset sales amid challenging hospitality environment
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Braemar Hotels & Resorts (BHR) Q4 2025

Management View

  • Richard Stockton, President and CEO, highlighted the ongoing sale process for Braemar, noting that "the company has engaged Robert W. Baird & Co as its financial adviser and the sale process has been initiated." Stockton indicated there is no set deadline for completion and added, "we have also appointed real estate broker co-advisers to evaluate the potential for individual asset sales in conjunction with the company's sale process." He emphasized "our comparable fourth quarter RevPAR was flat, our portfolio delivered 1.8% growth in comparable total revenue this quarter. Our resorts continued to deliver strong growth with comparable fourth quarter RevPAR increasing 4.1% and comparable hotel EBITDA increasing 6%." Stockton also stated that, excluding hotels under renovation, "our RevPAR growth was 2.6% and comparable hotel EBITDA increased 6.4%."

  • Stockton reported the sale of the 410-room Clancy in San Francisco for $115 million, noting it represents "a 5.2% capitalization rate on net operating income for the trailing 12 months ended September 30, 2025. In conjunction with that sale, the company paid down approximately $65 million of debt and retained approximately $44 million of net proceeds." He added, "to date, we have redeemed approximately $149 million of our non-traded preferred stock, which represents approximately 32% of the original capital raise."

  • Deric Eubanks, CFO, stated, "for the quarter, we reported net loss attributable to common stockholders of $46 million or $0.67 per diluted share and AFFO per diluted share of negative $0.02." Eubanks added, "Adjusted EBITDAre for the quarter was $28.8 million. Adjusted EBITDAre for the full year was $147 million."

  • Eubanks announced, "as of the end of the fourth quarter, we had approximately 46.7% net debt to gross assets. We ended the quarter with cash and cash equivalents of $124.4 million plus restricted cash of $42.5 million." He also explained the updated preferred equity securities dividend declaration process, stating, "we are moving from declaring Series B and Series D dividends at the start of the quarter to reserving them on a monthly basis alongside our other Series E and Series M monthly dividend declarations."

  • Christopher Nixon, Senior VP & Head of Asset Management, reported, "comparable hotel RevPAR was flat for the quarter, but we did achieve a 5.4% improvement in ADR compared to the prior year period."

Outlook

  • Management did not issue new specific forward-looking guidance but expressed optimism. Nixon stated, "we remain confident in our ability to sustain operating momentum and deliver strong results in the periods ahead" and "we are pleased with our solid performance and continue to see the benefits of initiatives focused on productivity and cost efficiency."

  • Stockton affirmed, "we are pleased with the performance of our portfolio and believe the renovations have recently -- that we have recently completed will drive strong performance going forward."

Financial Results

  • The company reported a net loss attributable to common stockholders of $46 million or $0.67 per diluted share and AFFO per diluted share of negative $0.02 for the quarter.

  • For the full year, net loss attributable to common stockholders was $72.7 million or $1.07 per diluted share and AFFO per diluted share of $0.28. Adjusted EBITDAre for the quarter stood at $28.8 million, with the full year at $147 million.

  • Portfolio delivered comparable fourth quarter RevPAR of $340, in line with the prior year quarter. Resort portfolio reported comparable RevPAR of $536, a 4.1% increase, and comparable hotel EBITDA of $32.5 million, a 6% increase over the prior year period.

  • The Ritz-Carlton Sarasota posted comparable RevPAR growth of approximately 26%, while Four Seasons Resort Scottsdale and Bardessono Hotel & Spa each delivered comparable RevPAR growth of approximately 12%. Ritz-Carlton Reserve, Dorado Beach, achieved comparable RevPAR of $1,806, up 10% over the prior year quarter.

  • During the fourth quarter, the company invested approximately $78 million in capital expenditures and anticipates spending between $25 million and $35 million in 2026.

Q&A

  • There were no analyst questions during the Q&A segment, and the call concluded without further discussion.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts did not raise any concerns or questions as there were no participants in the Q&A segment, resulting in a neutral sentiment.

  • Management maintained a confident and slightly positive tone throughout the prepared remarks, with repeated references to "pleased with our solid performance" and optimism regarding the impact of renovations and portfolio strength.

  • Compared to the previous quarter, management’s tone remained steady and positive, while the lack of analyst participation meant no change in analyst sentiment.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The current quarter emphasized the impact of renovations and asset sales, notably the completion and proceeds from the Clancy sale. In the previous quarter, the focus was also on asset sales and refinancing activities, but this quarter saw the actual completion of the Clancy sale.

  • Management highlighted continued growth in resort performance, with comparable RevPAR growth for resorts at 4.1% in Q4 compared to 5.5% in Q3. Portfolio RevPAR performance was flat in Q4, down from 1.4% growth in the prior quarter, but EBITDA growth in resorts remained robust.

  • Management tone was consistently optimistic about cost efficiency and resilience, while the absence of analyst Q&A this quarter removed a source of scrutiny seen previously.

  • Strategic focus remains on deleveraging, asset repositioning, and maximizing portfolio value amid the ongoing sale process.

Risks and Concerns

  • Stockton reiterated that the sale process has no deadline or definitive timetable and noted there is "no assurance that this process will result in the sale of the company or its assets."

  • Renovation disruptions impacted results at key properties, though management expects completed renovations to drive future performance.

  • Eubanks noted the company has not declared a common equity dividend policy for 2026 due to the ongoing sale process, stating, "the Board has not declared a policy for 2026 in light of the fact that there is an ongoing company sale process."

Final Takeaway

Management underscored Braemar’s resilience amid a challenging hospitality environment, highlighting strong resort performance, successful asset sales, ongoing deleveraging, and substantial capital investments. The company remains optimistic that recent renovations and continued focus on cost efficiency will support future growth, while the ongoing sale process and absence of a common dividend policy introduce elements of uncertainty for shareholders.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: ANI Pharmaceuticals targets over $1B in 2026 revenue with rare disease focus and expanded sales force
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: ANI Pharmaceuticals (ANIP) Q4 2025

Management View

  • Nikhil Lalwani, President, CEO & Director, highlighted record revenue, adjusted non-GAAP EBITDA, and adjusted non-GAAP diluted EPS for 2025, noting "full year revenues up 44% year-over-year and adjusted non-GAAP EBITDA by 47% year-over-year." He emphasized that Cortrophin Gel revenues rose 76% year-over-year and that the generics business grew 28%. The company set three priorities for 2026: transformation into a leading rare disease company, continued generics execution, and disciplined capital allocation. Lalwani announced a new 90-person organization dedicated to acute gouty arthritis flares, with plans to "capture sizable and unique additional opportunity in gout through expanding awareness and adoption of Cortrophin" and to "deliver over $1 billion in revenue, representing 23% growth over 2025 at the midpoint of our guidance range."
  • Christopher Mutz, Senior VP & Head of Rare Disease, reported that Cortrophin Gel prescribing in acute gouty arthritis represented about "15% of total utilization" and that ophthalmology volumes more than doubled year-over-year. He stated, "Cortrophin Gel is the only approved ACTH therapy for acute gouty arthritis flares," and outlined the rollout of a 90-person team to target this opportunity, building on successful pilot programs.
  • Stephen Carey, Senior VP of Finance & CFO, said, "ANI recorded revenues of $247.1 million in the fourth quarter, up 30% over the prior year period," and "Cortrophin Gel delivered $347.8 million of net revenue, up 76% year-over-year." He added, "Adjusted non-GAAP diluted earnings per share was $2.33 for the fourth quarter compared to $1.63 per share in the prior year period." Carey reiterated 2026 guidance and noted cash and leverage positions.

Outlook

  • The company reaffirmed 2026 guidance with net revenue of "$1.055 billion to $1.115 billion, representing year-over-year growth of approximately 19% to 26%." Cortrophin Gel net revenue is expected at "$540 million to $575 million, representing year-over-year growth of 55% to 65%." Adjusted non-GAAP EBITDA guidance is "$275 million to $290 million." Adjusted non-GAAP EPS is expected between "$8.83 and $9.34." ILUVIEN net revenue is forecasted at "$78 million to $83 million." Carey indicated that Q1 Cortrophin revenue will be seasonally lower, followed by sequential growth through the year.

Financial Results

  • ANI reported Q4 2025 revenues of "$247.1 million," with full year revenues of "$883.4 million." Cortrophin Gel Q4 revenues reached "$111.4 million." ILUVIEN brought in "$19.8 million" in Q4 and "$74.9 million" for the year. Generics Q4 revenue was "$100.8 million." Non-GAAP gross margin for Q4 was "59.6%," with full year gross margin at "61.6%." Non-GAAP SG&A for the year was "$264.6 million." Adjusted non-GAAP EBITDA was "$65.4 million" for Q4 and "$229.8 million" for the year. Year-end unrestricted cash was "$285.6 million," and principal debt stood at "$629.1 million."

Q&A

  • Glen Santangelo, Barclays: Asked about Cortrophin's multiyear opportunity and potential peak sales. Lalwani: The addressable populations are "significantly underpenetrated... we see a significant multiyear growth runway for the category and also for Cortrophin." On royalties, "In 2025 itself, we were in the highest royalty tier... blended royalty rate to be in the high 20s in 2026."
  • David Amsellem, Piper Sandler: Inquired about operating leverage with sales force expansion and duration of treatment across indications. Lalwani: "We're still in high-growth mode... We're keeping the EBITDA margin percentage the same in '26 versus '25 despite a year of very significant investment." He explained that treatment duration varies by indication.
  • Vamil Divan, Guggenheim: Asked about leveraging the gout sales team and business development plans. Lalwani: The new team "can be leveraged both for other indications... and also by adding another product in the basket." Carey: The company prefers a "reasonably conservative approach" to leverage for M&A.
  • Yuchen Ding, Jefferies: Asked about first-half weighting and confidence in gout expansion, and about royalty buy-downs. Lalwani: Cited "large underpenetrated market opportunity" and pilot program success, with field force impact expected in Q3 and Q4.
  • Ekaterina Knyazkova, JPMorgan: Asked about changes in patient access. Lalwani: "We have not seen material changes from an access perspective."
  • Thomas Smith, Leerink: Asked about gout utilization and pilot program learnings. Lalwani: The 15% gout share is expected to "increase significantly" with the new team; pilot programs informed targeting of key HCPs.
  • Leszek Sulewski, Truist: Asked about gout trends, ILUVIEN access, and generics cadence. Lalwani: Gout volume share will expand; ILUVIEN guidance assumes no major funding return; generics to maintain 10–15 launches per year.
  • Brandon Folkes, H.C. Wainwright: Asked about ACTH market dynamics. Lalwani: Growth is "not about share capture at all. This is about market expansion."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analyst sentiment was positive, with repeated focus on the sustainability and magnitude of Cortrophin growth, sales force ROI, and market expansion. Multiple analysts pressed for details on opportunity sizing and confidence in guidance.
  • Management maintained a confident and optimistic tone in prepared remarks, frequently expressing belief in "significant multiyear growth opportunity" and referencing high ROI on expansion initiatives. In Q&A, management was thorough and assertive, emphasizing the underpenetrated market and past success of commercial investments.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, both management and analysts sustained a positive tone, though current questions reflected deeper interest in execution risks linked to the large sales force expansion and new targets.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance for 2026 is more specific than in Q3, projecting over $1B in revenue and rare disease comprising 60% of revenues. Prior guidance called for "39% to 42%" revenue growth in 2025; current guidance targets "19% to 26%" growth for 2026, signaling a continued but moderating trajectory.
  • The strategic focus sharpened on Cortrophin Gel's gout opportunity, with the launch of a dedicated 90-person team in 2026, versus the portfolio team expansion in early 2025.
  • Analysts in Q4 focused on risk and execution of the new sales model, while Q3 centered on underlying demand and market penetration.
  • Key metrics such as gross margin showed a slight decline quarter-over-quarter, attributed to product mix and royalty impact.
  • Management's confidence in capturing the multiyear Cortrophin opportunity was consistent, but more emphasis was placed on operational execution and capital deployment in the current quarter.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management noted lower Q1 revenues due to "seasonality related to the impact of insurance reverifications" and weather disruptions, but expressed confidence in recovery.
  • Gross margin is expected to decline in 2026, due to "significantly higher forecast sales of royalty-bearing products" and the "non-recurrence of revenues from our first half 2025 180-day exclusive launch of Prucalopride."
  • Analysts raised concerns about the execution risk of the new sales force and the timing of returns from these investments.
  • The potential for royalty expense increases was discussed, with management indicating the royalty rate is now at its cap.
  • No material changes in payer access or reimbursement were reported.

Final Takeaway

ANI Pharmaceuticals concluded 2025 with record financial performance, led by rapid growth in its rare disease and generics businesses. For 2026, the company is targeting more than $1 billion in revenue and expects rare disease products to account for about 60% of total revenue. The strategic expansion of a dedicated sales force for acute gouty arthritis flares and continued investment in Cortrophin Gel and ILUVIEN position the company for further growth. Management emphasized disciplined capital allocation and reiterated confidence in achieving guidance, while acknowledging operational and market access risks remain actively managed.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Main Street Capital anticipates continued strong lower middle market activity with $1.04 DNII per share outlook for Q1 2026
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Main Street Capital Corporation (MAIN) Q4 2025

Management View

  • CEO Dwayne Hyzak stated that Main Street Capital is "extremely pleased with our continued strong performance in the fourth quarter, which closed another great year for Main Street." He cited a return on equity of 17.7% for the quarter and 17.1% for the full year, alongside record NAV per share for the 14th consecutive quarter and record annual gross lower middle market investments. Hyzak noted, "We remain confident that our unique investment income and value creation drivers together with our cost-efficient operations and conservative capital structure will allow us to continue to deliver superior results for our shareholders in the future."
  • Hyzak highlighted significant realizations, including the exit of Mystic Logistics in Q4 and KBC Industries in Q1 2026, both resulting in material realized gains and strong dividend flows over the life of the investments. He emphasized ongoing interest from potential buyers in other lower middle market portfolio companies and "expect[s] the strong contributions to continue."
  • Main Street added five new lower middle market portfolio companies in Q4, with a net increase in investments of $253 million, marking the highest quarterly activity since Q4 2021. The private loan portfolio saw a net increase of $109 million.
  • Hyzak announced a supplemental dividend of $0.30 per share payable in March 2026 and regular monthly dividends for Q2 2026 of $0.26 per share, a 4% increase from Q2 2025. He noted, "We currently expect to recommend that our Board continue to declare future supplemental dividends."
  • President and Chief Investment Officer David Magdol reflected on nearly two decades of performance, stating, "Since our IPO in 2007, we have increased our monthly dividends per share by 136%, and we have declared cumulative total dividends to our shareholders of more than $49 per share." Magdol pointed to $700 million deployed in lower middle market strategy in 2025, the largest year of originations in the company's history.
  • CFO Ryan Nelson reported, "Our total investment income for the fourth quarter was $145.5 million, increasing by $5.1 million or 3.6% over the fourth quarter of 2024 and increasing by $5.7 million or 4.1% from the third quarter of 2025." Nelson added, "NAV per share increased by $0.55 over the third quarter and by $1.68 per share or 5.3% when compared to a year ago, to a record NAV per share of $33.33 at year-end."

Outlook

  • Hyzak described the lower middle market investment pipeline as "above average," with expectations for "strong lower middle market investment activity in the first quarter." He stated that Main Street anticipates proposing another significant supplemental dividend payable in June 2026, contingent on continued strong performance and favorable DNII.
  • Nelson projected, "We expect first quarter of 2026 DNII before taxes of at least $1.04 per share with the potential for upside driven by portfolio investment activities during the quarter."

Financial Results

  • Nelson reported total investment income for Q4 2025 of $145.5 million, up 3.6% year-over-year and 4.1% sequentially. Dividend income increased by $11.4 million compared to a year ago, and fee income rose by $900,000.
  • The ratio of total operating expenses, excluding interest expense, as a percentage of average total assets was 1.4% for the quarter on an annualized basis and 1.3% for the year.
  • Net fair value appreciation, including net realized gains and net unrealized depreciation, totaled $42.5 million for the quarter. Net realized gains recognized in the quarter were $50.8 million.
  • Investments on nonaccrual status represented approximately 1% of the total investment portfolio at fair value and 3.3% at cost at year-end.
  • Main Street ended the quarter with cash and unused capacity under credit facilities totaling over $1.2 billion, and a near-term debt maturity of $500 million in July 2026.

Q&A

  • Robert Dodd, Raymond James: Asked about the sustainability of high investment activity and whether it signals a step change. Hyzak responded, "We've been intentional for the last couple of years about trying to grow our activities in the lower middle market, that includes growing our team." Magdol added, "Q4 was a particularly strong originations quarter. In the future, we hope to be able to continue momentum at above average rates, but I wouldn't say that Q4 is necessarily an indicative view towards our expectations going forward."
  • Dodd followed up on software exposure. Hyzak replied, "We do not have significant software exposure at all. We're value-based investors. We love basic industries... So we don't chase stuff that has high valuations."
  • Brian Mckenna, Citizens JMP Securities: Asked about ROE resilience and drivers. Hyzak explained, "I think when you look at the current environment, 2 things will impact our ROE going forward on the private credit, private loan side, both floating index rates and spreads... On lower middle market side, just the overall economy will be a big driver of where our ROE shakes out."
  • Arren Cyganovich, Truist Securities, asked about the talent pipeline. Hyzak responded, "We feel really good about the group of directors and VPs that we have beneath that... In the case of all those people, they are not people we hired from outside, these are people that have been at Main Street for a long period of time, executing to our strategies."
  • Douglas Harter, UBS: Asked about portfolio performance and areas of focus. Hyzak noted, "I wouldn't say we're seeing any area of any sector industry or specific area that's seeing more pressure, more underperformance."
  • Mckenna inquired about asset management business growth. Hyzak indicated, "We do expect to have growth in the future. Obviously, we have to have execution and the market had to be cooperative, but I do think we expect to have an increase in the base management fees there primarily as MC Income Fund executes just growth opportunity and its strategy."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed curiosity about the sustainability of investment activity, the impact of team expansion, sector exposures, and the outlook for ROE and asset management growth. The tone was neutral to slightly positive, with an emphasis on understanding potential changes in activity levels and operational resilience.
  • Management maintained a confident and constructive tone in prepared remarks, frequently referencing strong historical performance and the effectiveness of their differentiated investment strategy. During Q&A, management provided detailed, direct responses, acknowledging economic uncertainties but reiterating confidence in portfolio quality and strategy. Hyzak stated, "We remain confident that our unique investment income and value creation drivers... will allow us to continue to deliver superior results."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management’s tone was similarly positive, but more emphasis was placed on the record pace of lower middle market investments and continued dividend growth. Analysts’ tone remained stable, with questions focused on the implications of heightened activity and future returns.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Q4 saw a pronounced increase in lower middle market investment activity ($253 million net increase vs. $61 million in Q3) and the addition of five new portfolio companies compared to three in Q3.
  • Guidance for DNII per share in Q1 2026 was explicitly stated at "at least $1.04 per share," following Q4 DNII before taxes per share of $1.11 (Q3 was $1.07).
  • NAV per share set a new record for the 14th consecutive quarter, with a sequential increase of $0.55 vs. $0.48 in Q3.
  • Both quarters featured supplemental dividends of $0.30 per share and regular dividend increases, but Q4’s regular monthly dividend guidance reflected a 4% increase from the previous year.
  • Investment pipeline was described as "above average" in both quarters, but Q4 commentary emphasized robust follow-on investments and the potential for continued strong activity into Q1 2026.
  • Management’s confidence remained high, with a consistent focus on conservative capital structure, robust liquidity, and internally cultivated talent.

Risks and Concerns

  • Hyzak acknowledged challenges from floating index rates and spreads impacting private credit returns, and broader economic uncertainties influencing lower middle market results.
  • Limited software and low-end consumer exposure were identified as areas receiving increased attention, though current exposure is minimal.
  • Investments on nonaccrual status remained low at approximately 1% of fair value.
  • Management reiterated the importance of underwriting to cycles and maintaining a conservative leverage profile as key risk mitigants.

Final Takeaway

Main Street Capital highlighted elevated lower middle market investment activity, record NAV per share, and growing recurring and supplemental dividends, driven by robust portfolio performance and disciplined execution. The company projects continued strength into Q1 2026, underpinned by a strong investment pipeline, conservative capital structure, and a focus on internally developed talent. Management signaled expectations for further growth in asset management income and ongoing resilience in core returns, positioning the company for continued value creation for shareholders in the coming quarters.
